text:
So yesterday a ton of people fled the tier 4 regions; where the extra contagious strain is concentrated.
Prior to today's restrictions on travel outside of those regions.
This sounds similar to Italy in March.

text: exactly, on March 8th thousands of people fled out of Milan because there was a rumour it'd be put under lockdown the day after

text: the result was that whole Italy went under lockdown after two days

text:
England never seemed to get behind this idea of restricting travel between regions.
Western Australia when hard on it breaking the state into 7 regions.
Including splitting all 4 major population centers.
And requiring authorization to travel between them.

elements.text:

Western Australia when hard on it breaking the state into 7 regions.
Including splitting all 4 major population centers.
And requiring authorization to travel between them.

text:
I saw an article on a small nation with a bunch of islands that had rapidly stamped out covid with very few restrictions. Except that they allowed no travel between islands and broken their bigger islands into two regions.
I don't know that it was a good science.

elements.text:
I saw an article on a small nation with a bunch of islands that had rapidly stamped out covid with very few restrictions. Except that they allowed no travel between islands and broken their bigger islands into two regions.
I don't know that it was a good science.

text:
From the start I have been surprised at how little England wants to stop travel.
I really thought they would be shutting down trains in March, or at least restricting them.
But nope. I don't even know that they restricted them at the height of the first wave

text: Finland put the capitol area (Helsinki and surroundings) in travel lockdown in the spring, to be able to go in or out required paperwork. The result was that a lot of people fled to summer cottages before that, and a lot of job related traffic continued. It’s not believed that it had much any effect.

elements.text: Finland put the capitol area (Helsinki and surroundings) in travel lockdown in the spring, to be able to go in or out required paperwork. The result was that a lot of people fled to summer cottages before that, and a lot of job related traffic continued. It’s not believed that it had much any effect.

text: Restricting travel between countries has likely had more effect.

elements.text: Restricting travel between countries has likely had more effect.

text:
Depends on the stage of the pandemic and the location of the epicentre . The epidemic ground zero of Estonia in spring was the island of Saaremaa.

The government imposed a lockdown on the island and cut off all travel to the mainland. The rest of country faced almost no restrictions (ferry and flight travel restrictions excluded). That containment strategy was extremely successful.

Now the virus is spreading in the whole country, in  particular in the capital and the eastern region. Trying to cut off Tallinn would probably have the same effect as trying to cut off Helsinki.

elements.text:
Depends on the stage of the pandemic and the location of the epicentre . The epidemic ground zero of Estonia in spring was the island of Saaremaa.

The government imposed a lockdown on the island and cut off all travel to the mainland. The rest of country faced almost no restrictions (ferry and flight travel restrictions excluded). That containment strategy was extremely successful.

Now the virus is spreading in the whole country, in  particular in the capital and the eastern region. Trying to cut off Tallinn would probably have the same effect as trying to cut off Helsinki.
